title: First Bank of the United States
description: Chartered to stabilize the young nation's credit and improve handling of government finances under Hamilton's financial plan.

title: Panic of 1819
description: The first major U.S. financial crisis, triggered by speculative lending, falling cotton prices, and credit contraction.

title: Panic of 1837
description: A severe financial panic caused by speculative lending and Jackson's dismantling of the Second Bank of the U.S.

title: National Banking Act
description: Created a system of national banks and a uniform national currency during the Civil War.

title: Panic of 1873
description: Financial panic following railroad speculation collapse and the failure of Jay Cooke & Co., leading to a depression.

title: Panic of 1893
description: A major economic depression marked by railroad failures, bank collapses, and high unemployment.

title: Federal Reserve Act
description: Established the Federal Reserve System as the central bank of the United States.

title: Stock Market Crash
description: The Wall Street Crash of 1929 triggered the Great Depression, the worst economic downturn in U.S. history.

title: Glass-Steagall Act
description: Separated commercial and investment banking and created the FDIC to protect depositors.

title: Bretton Woods Agreement
description: Established a new international monetary system with fixed exchange rates and created the IMF and World Bank.

title: Nixon Ends Gold Standard
description: President Nixon ended the direct convertibility of the U.S. dollar to gold, ushering in the era of fiat currency.

title: Savings and Loan Crisis
description: Over 1,000 savings and loan institutions failed due to risky lending and deregulation, costing taxpayers billions.

title: Global Financial Crisis
description: Collapse of housing bubble and major banks sparked the worst global financial crisis since the Great Depression.

title: Dodd-Frank Act
description: Sweeping financial reform law aimed at preventing another financial crisis, increasing oversight of Wall Street.
